summary: Urged rejection of antisemitism and all forms of hate; emphasized that Israelis and Palestinians alike deserve safety, dignity, and equal respect for their rights. Additionally supports shining a light on Minority Serving Institutions by requiring the SBIR/STTR award database to identify MSIs and collect MSI participation data to encourage diverse partnerships and increase equity in access to federal R&D awards. Condemned the Trump Administration's decision to use Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst as an immigrant detention center as an inhumane policy that has led to unlawful deportation of U.S. citizens (including children) and called for its immediate reversal. More recently publicly condemned abusive ICE tactics (including harassment, unconstitutional searches, and a fatal shooting) and tied civil-rights concerns to his decision to vote against DHS funding, arguing DHS must rein in ICE and allow robust congressional oversight to protect communities and civil liberties. In a January 20, 2025 statement responding to President Trump's inaugural address, he pledged to "stand up for the American people" and to "fight back against any attempts by this Administration or Congressional Republicans to take the rights of anyone living in this country away," framing defense of civil rights as a central commitment while also calling for bipartisan work where possible.

Gill supports nationality-based immigration restrictions and has proposed codifying travel restrictions targeting a specific national-origin group (Somalis). He frames such measures as consistent with historical precedent and necessary for public safety and assimilation concerns, and has criticized Somali communities for failing to assimilate and relying on public benefits. He also supports restricting nationals from 'adversarial' countries from studying in the United States through the Student Visa Integrity Act, framing nationality-based bans and enhanced screening as necessary to protect national security and prevent abuse of immigration programs. In November 2025 he advanced the Expedited Removal of Criminal Aliens Act, which would make criminal aliens ineligible for withholding of removal and limit asylum-related protections for those convicted of violent crimes, gang members, or terrorists—reflecting support for narrowing certain asylum/withholding protections in the name of preventing abuse. In February 2025 he joined House Judiciary Committee Republicans in filing an amicus brief supporting President Trump's executive order on birthright citizenship, arguing the Fourteenth Amendment's reference to 'jurisdiction' should be read through an 'allegiance' lens and signaling support for narrowing automatic birthright citizenship. He also led RSC members in pressing the Senate to mark up the Safeguard American Voter Eligibility (SAVE) Act, a bill passed by the House that would require proof of citizenship to register to vote; Gill framed the measure as preventing illegal aliens from voting and an element of election integrity, urging Senate action and criticizing Senate leaders for blocking the bill. In July 2025 he co-introduced the Restoring Equal Opportunity Act with Sen. Mike Lee to permanently codify President Trump's executive order restoring merit-based, race-neutral decision making in hiring and housing by ending the use of 'disparate impact' claims under Title VII and the Fair Housing Act. He framed DEI and disparate-impact enforcement as leading to race-based quotas and legal threats to employers and housing providers, promoted 'merit' and 'equality under the law,' and secured backing from conservative organizations such as Heritage Action, Citizens for Renewing America, and CURE.

Raised concerns that DHS/ICE agents used chemical agents and force against civilians, journalists, and a Member of Congress, arguing these actions threaten constitutional protections, press freedom, and civil liberties and calling for review and accountability. Condemned an ICE raid in Tucson in which she and her staff say they were pushed aside and pepper-sprayed after identifying as congressional staff, asking how community members without such protections are treated. Also highlighted Border Patrol entry into a humanitarian aid site without a warrant and framed such tactics as terrorizing communities and undermining due process and human rights; has supported release of government records and accountability for abuses. Has also cosponsored the Equality Act and reproductive- and contraception-protecting legislation, reflecting broader civil-rights commitments. Most recently publicly condemned a Border Patrol raid of the No More Deaths humanitarian aid site in southern Arizona, alleging agents entered a protected structure without a warrant, arrested migrants resting inside, and thereby violated Fourth Amendment protections and due process rights while criminalizing humanitarian aid. Additionally condemned the killing of Renee Nicole Good by a federal agent in Minneapolis, criticized a federally-controlled probe that shut out state and local authorities, and tied these federal practices to patterns of racial profiling and fearmongering seen in Arizona (including SB1070) and in local raids where chemical irritants were used against community members and journalists. Also championed protections for Tribal Nations' religious freedom and cultural practices by introducing the Save Oak Flat from Foreign Mining Act to repeal a land-transfer rider that would have ceded the sacred Oak Flat (Chi’chil Biłdagoteel) to foreign mining interests without tribal consultation. Recently denounced a House-passed DHS funding bill that she says expands ICE funding while stripping oversight offices and failing to impose basic safeguards, citing warrantless home entries, use of children as bait, pepper-spraying of journalists and peaceful protestors, raids on humanitarian aid camps, racial profiling, and the terrorization of communities as civil-rights violations that demand accountability. She has also decried the militarization of cities and called for dismantling ICE as part of protecting civil liberties. Most recently condemned a fatal shooting by an ICE agent in Minneapolis, arguing ICE's activities cause chaos and violence and demanding accountability and investigation into the incident.
